question: Before March 31, 2025, will Israel or Hamas accuse the other of violating the ceasefire agreed to on January 15, 2025?
description: The Guardian: [Gaza ceasefire has come into effect but will the Israel-Hamas agreement hold?](https://www.theguardian.com/world/2025/jan/19/gaza-ceasefire-will-israel-hamas-agreement-hold)
news:
Here are the relevant news articles:

**Israeli Army Admits to Violating Ceasefire Agreement with Hamas**
The Israeli army has admitted to violating the ceasefire agreement with Hamas by opening fire on Palestinians and a vehicle in the Gaza Strip, citing that they posed a threat to their own forces. According to a statement from the Israeli army, their forces have been firing at suspected individuals who were approaching them and posing a threat in some areas of the Gaza Strip. The statement also mentioned that an Israeli drone fired at a vehicle that was passing through a restricted area, in violation of the ceasefire agreement. Despite admitting to multiple violations, the Israeli army claims to have fully complied with the ceasefire agreement and is ready for any scenario in the Gaza Strip. The ceasefire agreement between Hamas and Israel went into effect on January 19, 2025, at 12:15 PM local time. Between October 7, 2023, and the implementation of the ceasefire, Israeli attacks on the Gaza Strip resulted in the deaths of approximately 47,417 Palestinians, including 17,841 children and 12,298 women, and injured 111,571 people. Many are still trapped under the rubble, and hospitals and educational institutions, which were used as shelters by the people, were also destroyed.
Original language: tr
Publish date: January 29, 2025 11:10 PM
Source:[Haberler](https://www.haberler.com/guncel/israil-ordusu-ateskes-anlasmasini-ihlal-etti-18315872-haberi/)

**Israeli Military Admits to Violating Ceasefire Agreement in Gaza Strip**
The Israeli military has admitted to violating the ceasefire agreement in the Gaza Strip. According to a statement from the military, their forces have been firing at suspected individuals who were approaching their positions in some areas of Gaza, citing a need to 'remove threats'. The statement also mentioned that an Israeli drone fired at a car that was traveling north through the middle of Gaza, allegedly violating the ceasefire agreement by passing through a restricted area. Despite multiple violations, the Israeli military claims to have fully complied with the ceasefire agreement and is ready for any scenario in the Gaza Strip. Between October 7, 2023, and the implementation of the ceasefire on January 19, 2024, approximately 47,417 Palestinians were killed, including 17,841 children and 12,298 women, while 111,571 people were injured. The Israeli military's attacks also destroyed civilian infrastructure, including hospitals and educational institutions, where many people were still trapped under the rubble. The ceasefire agreement and prisoner exchange between Hamas and Israel went into effect on January 19, 2024, at 12:15 PM local time.
Original language: tr
Publish date: January 29, 2025 10:57 PM
Source:[TRT haber](https://www.trthaber.com/haber/dunya/israil-ordusu-gazze-seridinde-ateskesi-ihlal-ettigini-itiraf-etti-896138.html)

**Israel Violates Ceasefire in Gaza, Leaving Two Dead and Seven Injured**
Two Palestinians were killed and seven others injured, including a child, on Sunday (26), after Israeli forces opened fire on civilians in Gaza, violating a ceasefire agreement, according to Anadolu news agency. A young man was killed and two others were injured in the west of the Nuseirat refugee camp, in the center of Gaza, a health source reported. Another teenager was shot and killed in the central region of Rafah, in the southernmost part of the enclave. The Israeli army also opened fire on a group of displaced people waiting for authorization to return to the north of Gaza, injuring five, including a child. Witnesses reported that hundreds of civilians spent the night in the cold, waiting for permits from the occupying forces to return to the north, as agreed upon in mid-January. Israeli authorities postponed the opening of the roads, scheduled for Sunday, by 24 hours, on the condition that settler Arbel Yehud would be released. The Hamas movement responded that Yehud will be handed over in the next prisoner exchange. The first phase of the step-by-step agreement, scheduled to last six weeks, went into effect on January 19, suspending the Israeli extermination war against the coastal enclave's civilian population. Since then, seven Israeli prisoners of war, including four soldiers, have been released in exchange for 290 Palestinian political prisoners. The Qatari-Egyptian-US mediated agreement ended the 470-day Israeli campaign in Gaza, which left at least 48,000 Palestinians dead, 111,000 injured, and around two million displaced. In January 2024, the International Court of Justice (ICJ) in The Hague accepted a South African complaint of genocide and war crimes against Tel Aviv, registered in December. In November, the International Criminal Court (ICC) issued arrest warrants for Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu and his former Defense Minister Yoav Gallant for war crimes and crimes against humanity committed in Gaza.
Original language: pt
Publish date: January 28, 2025 01:23 PM
Source:[monitordooriente.com](https://www.monitordooriente.com/20250128-israel-viola-cessar-fogo-em-gaza-deixa-dois-mortos-e-sete-feridos/)

**Israel Admits to Violating Ceasefire Agreement with Hamas**
The Israeli military has acknowledged that it violated a ceasefire agreement with Hamas by firing on Palestinians in the Gaza Strip, citing 'threats' from Palestinian individuals. According to a written statement, 'over the past 24 hours, our forces have taken concentrated action against suspects in the Gaza Strip who posed a threat to our security.' The statement claims that 'suspects' from various locations in the Gaza Strip were moving towards Israeli forces, posing a threat, and that multiple incidents occurred, prompting Israeli soldiers to fire on them. It has been reported that Israeli forces launched a ceasefire-violating attack on a vehicle in the Gaza Strip last night, resulting in the death of a girl and injuries to three civilians. Between October 7, 2023, and January 19, 2024, Israeli attacks on the Gaza Strip resulted in the deaths of 47,283 Palestinians, including 17,841 children and 12,298 women, and injuries to 111,472 Palestinians. Thousands of bodies remain buried under the rubble, civilian infrastructure has been destroyed, and hospitals and educational institutions that serve as shelters have become targets of attack. The ceasefire and prisoner exchange agreement between Hamas and Israel went into effect at 12:15 PM Turkish time on January 19.
Original language: zh
Publish date: January 28, 2025 08:19 AM
Source:[TRT](https://www.trt.net.tr/chinese/guo-ji/2025/01/28/yi-se-lie-jun-fang-cheng-ren-wei-fan-ting-huo-xie-yi-2235083)

**Israel-Hamas Ceasefire: A Delicate Balance**
Israel and Hamas have a ceasefire agreement in place since January 19, 2024, after a brutal war in Gaza that lasted from October 2023. However, many experts believe that Israel may resume attacks in March. This would be challenging for Israel as millions of Palestinians are returning to northern Gaza, making it difficult for Benjamin Netanyahu. The future of Israel-Hamas relations is uncertain. If Israel resumes war, it would create a massive humanitarian crisis and isolate Israel internationally. Last year, Israel's attack was justified due to Hamas' attack on October 7, but this time, the global community may react differently. Israel would need to deploy a large number of soldiers if it resumes war, which could be a challenge. The military's reserve forces are also a concern. Politically, Netanyahu would face challenges at home and internationally. The Israeli public is already exhausted from a long war. Experts believe that Israel may not have the option for a full-scale war and may instead continue with small operations to pressure Hamas. However, this would not lead to significant changes in Gaza.

**Israel Admits to Violating Ceasefire Agreement in Gaza Strip**
Israel has admitted to violating the ceasefire agreement with Hamas in the Gaza Strip. According to a statement from the Israeli military, they opened fire on Palestinians who were 'threatening' their forces, targeting a donkey cart. Source:[Haberler](https://www.haberler.com/dunya/israil-gazze-de-ateskesi-ihlal-ettiklerini-18308188-haberi/)

**Over 300,000 Palestinians Return Home in Gaza After Israel-Hamas Agreement**
More than 300,000 Palestinians displaced from the center and south of the Gaza Strip have returned to their homes in the north of the enclave, according to local authorities. The return was made possible by an agreement between Israel and Hamas, which allowed Palestinians to begin returning from the south of the Gaza Strip to the northern neighborhoods of the enclave in exchange for the release of three Israeli hostages before Friday. Hamas had released a second group of hostages last week as part of the agreement with Israel, which was initiated a week ago. In exchange for the release, 200 Palestinian prisoners, including those convicted of terrorism, were released. Fadi Al Sinwar, a resident of Gaza, said, 'We've been missing our home. We've been living in tents for 470 days.' Nadia Qassem, from the Al Shati refugee camp, said, 'We've been waiting for this day for so long,' although many will only find rubble where their homes once stood. 'I want to go home... Even if my house is destroyed. I miss my land and my place,' she said. The return was delayed by 48 hours after Israel accused Hamas of violating the terms of the ceasefire agreement by releasing the hostage Arbel Yehud, which delayed the opening of the Netzarim crossing that divides the territory. Hamas and Israel agreed to release more hostages, including Yehud, on Thursday and Saturday, according to the Office of the Israeli Prime Minister. The ceasefire agreement between Israel and Hamas, mediated by Qatar, Egypt, and the United States, was reached on January 15 and went into effect on January 19. The first phase of the agreement called for the exchange of 33 Israeli hostages held by Hamas for 1,000 Palestinian prisoners. Israeli forces will withdraw to the borders of the Gaza Strip, although they will remain within its limits for now.
Original language: es
Publish date: January 28, 2025 03:29 AM
Source:[laarena.com.ar](https://www.laarena.com.ar/el-mundo/mas-de-300-000-palestinos-vuelven-a-sus-hogares-20251280290)

**Israel Accuses Hamas of Violating Ceasefire Agreement**
Israel accuses Hamas of violating the ceasefire agreement by not providing information on the status of hostages to be released soon. According to The Times of Israel, Hamas failed to provide Israel with information on the status of the hostages by the end of Saturday, violating the terms of the ceasefire agreement. Israel also stated that Hamas failed to release a civilian hostage, Arbel Yegud, along with four female soldiers on Saturday, January 25. As a result, Israel will not allow the planned return of displaced Palestinians to the northern Gaza Strip until Yegud is released. This decision also means that the Israeli military, the IDF, will not withdraw its troops from the Netzarim Corridor, as planned for Sunday. The corridor divides the Gaza Strip in half from east to west and separates its south from its north. 'We will not allow the return of the displaced Palestinians to the northern Gaza Strip until Arbel Yegud is released,' said an Israeli official. The White House National Security Council representative stated on Saturday that the administration 'continues to insist on the release of Arbel Yegud.'

**Israel violates ceasefire by blocking return of displaced Gazans: Hamas**
Hamas accused Israel of violating a ceasefire agreement by blocking the return of displaced civilians to northern Gaza. Israel claims it will not allow the return of displaced Palestinians until Israeli captive Arbel Yehud is released. Hamas has informed mediators that Yehud is alive and has provided guarantees for her release. The ceasefire agreement, which took effect on January 19, suspended Israel's war on Gaza that has killed over 47,000 Palestinians and injured over 111,000 since October 7, 2023. The International Criminal Court has issued arrest warrants for Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu and former Defense Minister Yoav Gallant for war crimes and crimes against humanity in Gaza.
Original language: en
Publish date: January 26, 2025 03:26 PM
Source:[Yeni Şafak](https://www.yenisafak.com/en/news/israel-violates-ceasefire-by-blocking-return-of-displaced-gazans-hamas-3697670)

**Israel Accuses Hamas of Violating Ceasefire Agreement**
Israel has accused Hamas of violating the terms of the ceasefire agreement by not releasing Israeli hostage Arbel Yehud and not providing a list of living and dead captives. According to the Israeli Prime Minister's Office, Hamas has 'twice breached the agreement: Arbel Yehud has not been released, and the list of captives' current status for the first stage has not been provided.' As a result, Israel has decided to prevent the movement of Gaza residents to the north of the sector. Israel is making 'significant efforts' to resolve the issue of Arbel Yehud's release, with the US and other countries acting as mediators. 'We are determined to secure the return of all hostages - both living and dead,' the statement emphasized. Meanwhile, until the issue of Arbel Yehud's release is resolved, Israel will not allow peaceful residents to return to the north of the Gaza Strip, the Prime Minister's Office announced. Hamas had previously released a second group of hostages as part of the agreement, which began a week ago. In exchange, Israel released four Israeli soldiers from prison and freed 200 Palestinian prisoners, including those sentenced to life in prison for terrorism. According to Al Jazeera, Hamas has informed mediators that Arbel Yehud is alive and will be handed over to Israel on February 1. A Hamas representative claimed that Yehud is a military personnel and was training for the Israeli army. Bassam Na'im, a high-ranking Hamas representative, stated that Palestinians will never agree to US President Donald Trump's proposal to temporarily relocate the majority of Gaza's population to other areas, including Egypt and Jordan. 'Even if the intentions seem benevolent under the guise of reconstruction,' Na'im said, 'the Palestinian people will never agree to such a proposal.' He also stated that Palestinians can rebuild Gaza 'even better than before' if Israel lifts its blockade.

Publish date: January 26, 2025 01:59 PM
Source:[Deutsche Welle](https://www.dw.com/uk/izrail-zvinuvativ-hamas-u-porusenni-ugodi-pro-pripinenna-vognu/a-71415211)

**Israel Accuses Hamas of Violating Ceasefire Agreement**
Israel has accused Hamas of violating the terms of the ceasefire agreement by not releasing Israeli hostage Arbel Yehud and not providing a list of living and deceased captives. According to the Israeli Prime Minister's Office, Hamas has breached the agreement twice, failing to release Yehud and provide the list of captives. As a result, Israel has decided not to allow the movement of Gaza residents to the north of the sector. Israel is making significant efforts to resolve the issue of Yehud's release with the help of the US and other countries. 'We are determined to secure the return of all hostages, both living and deceased,' said Dmitry Gendelman, an advisor to the Israeli Prime Minister. The ceasefire agreement between Israel and Hamas began on January 19 and was set to last for 42 days. The agreement aimed to bring an end to the 15-month conflict that had resulted in the deaths of 46,000 Palestinians and 1,500 Israelis, and had spread to other countries in the region.
Original language: ru
Publish date: January 26, 2025 12:44 PM
Source:[informburo.kz](https://informburo.kz/novosti/izrail-obvinil-hamas-v-narushenii-sdelki-o-prekrashenii-ognya)

**Hamas and Israel Accuse Each Other of Violating Ceasefire Agreement**
Hamas has accused Israel of obstructing the return of Palestinians from the south to the north of the Gaza Strip, violating the ceasefire agreement. Israel claims that Hamas is violating the terms of the agreement. 'The occupiers are obstructing the return of displaced persons from the south to the north, which is a violation of the ceasefire agreement. They are using the case of hostage Erbil Yehud as a pretext, although the movement has informed mediators that she is alive and has provided all necessary guarantees for her release... We consider the occupying forces responsible for obstructing the implementation of the agreement, and we are following with the mediators with full responsibility to reach a solution that will lead to the return of displaced persons,' Hamas said in a statement. Israel, on the other hand, accused Hamas of not yet releasing Arbel Yehud and not providing a list of living and dead hostages. 'In connection with this, it was decided not to allow the movement of Gaza residents to the north of the sector,' said Dmitry Gendelman, an advisor to the Israeli prime minister's office. Yesterday, as part of the implementation of the agreement with Israel, Hamas released a second group of Israeli female soldiers, releasing three girls. The fourth, Arbel Yehud, remains in captivity, but the Palestinian movement has presented evidence that she is alive and has promised to release her during the next stage. In exchange, 200 Palestinian prisoners were released from Israeli prisons, including those sentenced to life for terrorism. In addition, Palestinians were supposed to receive the opportunity to return to the north from the south of the Gaza Strip, where they were forced to resettle due to military actions. Israel and Hamas agreed to a ceasefire with the mediation of Qatar, Egypt, and the United States on January 19 for 42 days and announced their desire to achieve a final end to the fighting, which over 15 months has killed 46,000 Palestinians and around 1,500 Israelis, then spread to Lebanon and Yemen, and sparked a rocket exchange between Israel and Iran. This is the second ceasefire during the conflict: the first was concluded in November 2023 and lasted only six days.

The Hamas movement accused Israel of violating the ceasefire agreement on January 26, 2025, by blocking the return of residents from the northern Gaza Strip, who had fled to the south due to bombings and fighting. The Hamas said they will 'follow the matter with the mediators' and 'hold Israel responsible for the delay in implementing the agreement.' Thousands of Palestinians gathered near the 'Netzarim Corridor,' which divides the Gaza Strip in two, from the Mediterranean Sea to the Israeli border.

**Hamas Accuses Israel of Violating Ceasefire Agreement in Gaza Strip**
Hamas accused Israel of violating the ceasefire agreement in the Gaza Strip, citing Israel's ban on displaced people returning to their homes in the northern Gaza Strip. According to Hamas, this is a 'clear violation of the ceasefire agreement'. Previously, it was reported that Israeli authorities had asked the administration of US President Donald Trump to use its influence on mediators, Egypt and Qatar, to secure the release of Israeli citizen Arbel Yehud. Hamas had previously handed over four Israeli hostages to the International Committee of the Red Cross. On January 17, Israel's military-political cabinet approved a ceasefire agreement in the Gaza Strip, which includes the release of 33 Israeli hostages in exchange for 1,000 Palestinian prisoners. Israeli forces will withdraw to the Gaza Strip borders, and humanitarian aid will be increased during the ceasefire. It was previously reported that Israel may resume its operation in Gaza after the release of the hostages.

Hamas accused Israel of violating the terms of the ceasefire agreement, stating that Palestinians are not allowed to return to the Gaza Strip territory. 'Hamas and mediators are monitoring Israel's actions, which prohibit displaced people from returning from southern Gaza regions to their homes in the north - this is a violation of the ceasefire agreement,' Hamas said in a statement. Israel responded with similar accusations, with Prime Minister's advisor Dmitry Gendelman stating that TEL Aviv will not allow Gaza residents to return to the north of the enclave because Hamas violated the agreement by not releasing Arbel Yehud and not providing lists of living and deceased hostages. On January 16, Hamas and Israel signed a ceasefire agreement in the Gaza Strip. **Israel Accuses Hamas of Violating Ceasefire Agreement in Gaza**
Israel accused Hamas of violating the ceasefire agreement in Gaza by releasing four Israeli soldier hostages before releasing civilian women hostages. According to Daniel Hagari, the Israeli military spokesperson, 'Hamás failed to comply with its obligations to release the Israeli civilian women first.' Israel had expressed its disagreement with the initial plan, but ultimately agreed to the release. The agreement calls for the release of 33 people in the first phase of the ceasefire, including seven women, five soldiers, and two civilians. However, the four released on Saturday were all soldiers, not civilians. The two civilians, Shiri Silberman and Arbel Yehud, were not released. Silberman was reportedly killed in an Israeli attack in November 2023, but this has not been confirmed. Israel had reportedly been pushing for Yehud's release, but it did not happen.

**Israel Accuses Hamas of Violating Ceasefire Agreement in Gaza**
Israel accused Hamas of violating the ceasefire agreement in Gaza by releasing four Israeli female soldiers before releasing civilian hostages, including Argentine citizen Shiri Silberman and her two young children. According to Israeli Army spokesperson Daniel Hagari, 'Hamas failed to comply with its obligations to release the Israeli civilian women first.' Israel had expressed its disagreement with the initial announcement, but ultimately agreed to the release. The agreement stipulated that 33 people were to be released in the first phase of the ceasefire, including seven women, five soldiers, and two civilians. Shiri Silberman and Arbel Yehud are the two civilians still held in Gaza. In November 2023, the Islamic Jihad claimed that Silberman and her children had died in an Israeli attack, but the Israeli Army never confirmed this information.

**Israel Accuses Hamas of Violating Agreement, Demands List of Hostages**
Israel has accused Hamas of violating the agreement and will not continue to fulfill its conditions until a list of hostages is provided. 'Israel will not tolerate any violations of the agreement. Full responsibility lies with Hamas,' emphasized Gendelman. He also clarified that according to the agreement, the names of the hostages must be provided no later than 16:00 local time (17:00 MSK) a day before their release. However, as of now, information about the hostages who are to be released tomorrow has not been received. It is worth noting that Israel and Hamas agreed to a ceasefire on January 19, 2024, for 42 days, with the mediation of Qatar, Egypt, and the United States. The parties expressed their desire to achieve a final end to the hostilities, which over the past 15 months have resulted in the deaths of 46,000 Palestinians and around 1,500 Israelis. The conflict has also affected Lebanon and Yemen, leading to rocket exchanges between Israel and Iran. Earlier, a political scientist revealed whether the agreement between Hamas and Israel could lead to the end of the conflict. According to him, a complete resolution is premature, and it is only possible with the creation of a Palestinian state.

**Israel Accuses Hamas of Reneging on Ceasefire Agreement**
The Israeli government has accused the Palestinian terrorist group Hamas of reneging on agreements reached in negotiations. According to a statement by Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, Hamas is 'violating agreements and creating a crisis at the last minute that prevents an agreement.' Netanyahu's office stated that the Israeli cabinet will not convene until the mediators inform Israel that Hamas has accepted all elements of the agreement. In contrast, Hamas has maintained that it remains committed to the ceasefire agreement in the Gaza Strip, as stated by Reuters, citing a Hamas representative, Izat al-Rishq. The agreement, announced on January 15, included a six-week ceasefire and the gradual withdrawal of Israeli troops from Gaza, as well as the release of hostages held by Hamas in exchange for Palestinian prisoners.

**Israel Accuses Hamas of Violating Ceasefire Agreement**
Israel has accused Hamas of violating the agreements reached on a ceasefire agreement. 'Hamas is refusing to accept the agreements reached and creating a crisis at the last minute, which prevents the agreement from being reached,' said a statement from the Prime Minister's Office. The statement added that the Israeli government 'will not convene until the mediators inform Israel that Hamas has accepted all elements of the agreement.' The agreement, which was reached on January 15, includes a ceasefire and the release of hostages. However, Hamas has refused to accept some of the terms, leading to a delay in the agreement. The Israeli government has warned that it will not proceed with the agreement until Hamas accepts all the terms. The conflict between Israel and Hamas began on October 7, 2023, when Hamas militants attacked Israeli territory, taking control of several towns and capturing dozens of hostages. Israel responded with a counter-terrorism operation, and the government declared a state of emergency. The conflict has resulted in a humanitarian crisis in Gaza, with the UN warning of a 'catastrophe'.

**Israel Accuses Hamas of Sabotaging Peace Agreement**
Israel has accused Hamas of sabotaging a peace agreement. According to a statement by the Prime Minister's office, Hamas refused to accept some of the terms of the agreement at the last minute, which has hindered the achievement of a ceasefire deal. The statement reads, 'Hamas is violating agreements and creating a crisis at the last minute, which is preventing the agreement, - said the Prime Minister's statement, published in English and Hebrew. - The Israeli cabinet will not convene until the mediators inform Israel that Hamas has accepted all elements of the agreement.' A ceasefire agreement was announced on January 15, which included a six-week period of ceasefire and the gradual withdrawal of Israeli forces from Gaza, as well as the release of hostages held by Hamas in exchange for Palestinian prisoners.

**Israel Accuses Hezbollah of Violating Ceasefire Agreement**
Israeli Defense Minister Israel Katz accused the Hezbollah group of not respecting the terms of the ceasefire agreement and warned that his country will 'act with force'. According to Katz, Hezbollah fighters have not retreated north of the Litani River in southern Lebanon, about 30 km from the Israeli border. 'If this condition is not met, there will be no agreement and Israel will be forced to act unilaterally to ensure the safe return of residents from the north to their homes', he added. Meanwhile, the Hamas Health Ministry reported that at least 88 Palestinians were killed in Gaza over the past 24 hours following Israeli attacks. The total number of deaths in the conflict that began on October 7, 2023 has risen to 45,805, with 109,064 injured. The Israeli army reported that it had struck 100 Hamas targets along the Gaza Strip, explaining that 'the terrorist organization launched numerous missiles from the Palestinian enclave towards Israel'. Before the attacks, the Israeli Defense Forces took numerous measures 'to mitigate the risk of harm to civilians, including the use of precision ammunition, aerial surveillance, and additional intelligence activities'.

forecasters.initial_reasoning: Historically, ceasefires in conflict zones such as those between Israel and Hamas have often been fragile and prone to violations. A ceasefire agreement between Israel and Hamas, considering their long-standing hostilities, has a high probability of being accused of breaches. Based on data from past ceasefires in similar conflict areas, approximately 70% have faced accusations of violations shortly after being agreed upon.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Recent Tensions
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: Recent tensions and hostilities prior to the ceasefire may sustain a high level of mistrust between the parties, increasing the likelihood of accusations of violations.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Ceasefire Monitoring
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: The presence of monitoring organizations can reduce the probability of accusations by fostering accountability, though it might not be fully effective in preventing minor violations.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Political Will
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: Both parties might have a vested interest in maintaining the ceasefire to avoid escalation, especially if there are diplomatic or internal political pressures encouraging restraint.

The Middle East ceasefire agreements often face challenges, with many past breaches or accusations of violations shortly after being established. Over the last two decades, ceasefires involving Israel and Hamas have typically seen accusations of violations within a few weeks to months after the ceasefire is imposed. For example, in ceasefire agreements such as those in 2009, 2012, 2014, and more recently, nearly all saw accusations of violations within a month or two. Based on this historical frequency, the probability of an accusation of violation can be initially set at a high level, around 70%.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Current Tensions
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: The current geopolitical context includes heightened tensions post-agreement, particularly if there are contentious issues unresolved by the ceasefire, such as border control or blockade conditions. This environment is conducive to incidents being interpreted as violations.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Internal Pressures
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: Both Israeli and Hamas leaderships face pressures internally (political factions, public expectations), which can lead to defensive postures and prompt accusations as a way to reinforce support or avert criticism.

perspective_derived_factors.name: International Mediation Efforts
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: International actors often play a role in monitoring and mediating ceasefires. However, their influence can vary, and in cases where their presence is not strong or seen as biased, the likelihood of accusations increases as trust in impartial observation decreases.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Winter Season
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: The winter season, historically, is relatively less active in terms of military conflict due to environmental conditions. This could lead to reduced military operations and thus fewer opportunities for accusations.

revised_reasoning.points_reinforcing_prior_analysis: Israel has admitted to violating the ceasefire agreement on multiple occasions, as reported by multiple credible sources. This admission confirms the expectation of ceasefire violations occurring soon after the agreement. Furthermore, Israel has accused Hamas of violating the ceasefire, indicating mutual accusations which are consistent with past patterns in Israeli-Hamas ceasefires.
revised_reasoning.points_challenging_prior_analysis: There are no significant news elements that directly challenge the prior analysis. Both parties admitting violations and accusations sustain the assessment provided in Phase 1.

forecasters.initial_reasoning: Ceasefire agreements in the context of Israel and Hamas have historically shown a high propensity for being violated or for accusations of violations shortly after their initiation. Given historical data, ceasefires in this context have about a 60-70% chance of one side accusing the other of violations within the first few months.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Previous ceasefire violations
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: Historically, ceasefires between Israel and Hamas have often been tenuous, with many previous instances of accusations of violations within weeks. This historical pattern strongly suggests that similar accusations are likely in this instance.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Current geopolitical tensions
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: As of early 2025, the geopolitical situation in the Middle East remains tense, with ongoing conflicts and hostilities in the region that might increase the likelihood of ceasefire violations. These dynamics often lead to escalations and accusations.

perspective_derived_factors.name: International monitoring presence
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: The presence of international monitors or mediators can sometimes reduce the likelihood or delay accusations by providing an additional layer of accountability and verification before accusations are made.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Public opinion and political pressures
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: Both Israel and Hamas are under significant pressure to maintain a semblance of order. However, domestic pressures can often lead to rapid accusations to satisfy internal hardline constituents or avoid appearing weak.

revised_reasoning.points_reinforcing_prior_analysis: Multiple news articles confirm that both Israel and Hamas have accused each other of violating the ceasefire agreement. Israeli military has admitted to firing on Palestinians, constituting a violation of the ceasefire as noted in several sources. Meanwhile, Hamas has accused Israel of obstructing the return of displaced persons, which they consider a ceasefire violation. These accusations from both sides align with the historical pattern of ceasefires between the two groups often facing violations.
revised_reasoning.points_challenging_prior_analysis: There are no significant points in the news articles that challenge the prior analysis. The admissions and accusations reported strongly corroborate the high likelihood of accusations, as initially forecasted.
